IX– 1 185 97
so that it may be quite obliterated
We went and spoke to the
people advising them to
keep together and support
the heir - They took this kindly
and in turn advised us
not to be alarmed for they
would not think of ascribing
the death to us - That Sebituane
had just gone the way of his
fathers and though the
father had gone he had left
children and they hoped
that we would be as friendly
to them ^ his children as we intended to
have been to hismself -

He was decidedly the
finest native chief I ever met
I never felt moreso much so much ^ grieved by
the loss of a black man ^ before than
by this - and it was impossible
not to follow him in
thought into the world of
which he had just heard
before he was called away,
and to realize somewhat
of the feelings of those
who pray for the dead -
The deep dark question
of what is to become of such
must however be left where
we find it - believing that
assuredly the "Judge of all
the earth will do right"
2 186
At ^ Sebituane's death the chieftainship
devolved on a daughter named
Ma mo-chisane as her father
intended - He had promised
to shewshow us his country and
select a suitable locality for
a residence but now the
daughter was living twelve
days to the North - at
Naliele - When We were nowthen
therefore obliged to remain untilluntil a
message came from her
and when it did she givinggave us perfect liberty to
visit any part of the
country we chose - Mr OswelOswell
and I therefore proceeded
130 miles ^ to the N. E.North East to Sesheke and
in the end of June 1851 were
rewarded by athe discovery
of the ZambesiZambezi in the
centre of the Continent -
This was a most important
point, for that river was
not previously never known to exist there
at all - The Portuguese maps
all represent it as rising
far to the East of where
we now were - and if ever
anything like a chain of
trading ^ stations existed accrossacross the
country between the latitudes
12˚ and 18˚ South this
magnificent portion of
the river must have
been known - We saw it
3 99 187
at the end of the dry season,
or at the time when the river
is about its lowest - and yet
we saw from 300 to 600 yards
of deep flowing water - Mr
O.Oswell ^ said he had never sawseen such a fine
river even in India - andthat
at the period of annual
inunda inundation it rises
fully 20 feet in perpendicular
height to flood fifteen or
twenty miles of country -
lands adjacent to its banks, The country over which
we had travelled from the
Chobe was perfectly flat
except where ^ there were large anthills
appeared or have beenthe remains of former ones
& left a ^ which had left mounds
a few feet high - These are generally
covered with wild date
trees and Palmyras
and ^ in some parts theirre
are patches of mimosae -
Occasionally the country
between the Chobe and Zambezi is flooded
and there are large patches
of swamp lying near
or on itsthe banks
of the former The Makololo
were living among these
swamps because of the
protection the deep ^ reedy rivers
afforded them against
their enemies

4 188 100
^ Now in reference
to a suitable locality
for a settlement
for myself I could
not conscientiously
ask them to
abandon their
defences for my
convenience alone
The healthy
districts were
defenceless - and
the safe localities
are so deleterious
to human life
that the original
BasutusBasutos had nearly all been cut off
by the fever I ^ therefore feared to
subject my family to
the scourge -

As we were the very first
white men the inhabitants
had ever seen, we were
visited by prodigious numbers -
Among the first who
came to see us we were
struck by was a gentleman
who appearinged in a gaudy
gown of printed calico.
Many of the Makololo
besides had garments of
blue, green, and red baize
and also of printed cottons
on enquiry we learned
that these had been purchased
with boys - from a tribe which
is situated near Bihé
in exchange for boys called Mambari - ^ This tribeThey came
and began the slave trade
with Sebituane only in
1850 - and but for the
unwillingness of Lechulatebe
to allow us to pass him
we should have been
with Sebituane in time
to ^ have prevented it from commencing
at all - The Mambari
visited the chief of the
Barotse whom Sebituane
conquered and he refused
5 189
to allow any one to sell a
child - They never came
back again till 1850 and
as they havinghad a number of
old Portuguese guns marked
"Legitimo de Braga" which
Sebituane thought would
be excellent in any other
invasion of MatibeleMatebele
he offered to purchase them
with cattle or ivory but
theythe Mambari refused everything but
except ^ boys - about 14 years of
age - The Makololo declare
they never heard of people
being bought and sold till
then and disliked it, but
the desire to possess the
guns prevailed and
eight old guns were
exchanged for as many
boys - These were not
bla their own children but
captives of the black races
they had conquered I have never
known ^ in Africa an instance
of a parent
selling his own
offspring - The
Makololo were afterwards
incited to make a foray
against some tribes to
the Eastward - The Mambari
bargaining to use their
guns for the captives
they might take and the
Makololo should ^ wa were to have
all the cattle - They went off
6 190
with at least 200 slaves
that year -

During this foray the
Makololo met some Arabs
from Zanzibar who
presented them with three
English muskets and
in return recievedreceived about
30 of their captives -

In talking with my
companion over these
matters the idea was suggested
that if the slave market
were supplied with articles
of European manufacture
in the way of by legitimate
trade commerce, the trade
in slaves would become
impossible - It seemed
more feasible to give the goods
for which the people now part
with their servants in exchange
for ivory ^ and other products
of the country and thus prevent
the initiative trade - thatnn to
put a stop to it ^ at any of the
subsequent steps - This
could only be effected by
establishing ^ a highway from the coast
into the centre of the country
As there was no hope of
of the Boers allowing the
peaceable instruction of
the natives at Kolobeng
I at once resolved to take
savesave my family from
7 191
exposure to this unhealthy region
by sending them to England
and to return alone with a
view to exploring the country
in search of a healthy
district that might prove
a centre of civilization
and open up the Interior
by a path to either the
East or West coasts -
This resolution led me down
to Cape Town in 18April 1852
being the first time during eleven
years that I had revisited
the scenes of civilization
======

In the minds of many English-
men I find the ideas of the
Cape and Kaffreir wars are
as ^ inseparably connected as
the Siamese twins, and it is
somewhat difficult for those
who live on a railway
island to realize the idea of
our little unprotected party
quietly travelling through the heart of
the colony to the capital in the twentieth
month of a
Kaffreir war with
as little sense of danger as
if we had been in England
# These Kaffreir wars are an
unmitigated nuisance - English
colonists are unquestionably
the best in the world - Neither
French nor Spaniards nor
Portuguese can be compared
to the sturdy manly Englishman
emigrant - He knows and acts on the
principle which other nations
are so slow to learn that
wives areand families are more
essential to prosperous
settlements than kettledrums
and bayonets - The English
wife must have a decent
house and things to match
and grumble as he willmay
he must follow her guidance
so far, ^ and confess ^ that she is an essential
9 193 105
element in upholding and promoting
civilization - successful colonization

All my experience inclines
me to the belief that in their dealings
with the natives of the English trader and Colonist
have payssome more regard is paid to the to justice
and honour than they assume
credit for - Nowhere can it
be fairly said that the wide
world wide reputation of
the British merchant for
honest determination to fufill
his engagements, has been
so entirely forgotten in an
English community as to
have it publicly considered a smart thing
to swindle either black
or white the aboriginiesaborigines -
To the poorest and most
degraded the Englishman
says "Live and let live" and
that has been the general
feeling of the English Government
too - The acts of different ministers
have been capabecapable ^ it is true of bearing
another interpretation,
but it must be conceded
that no disposition has ever
of late years ^ at least been shewnshown by the English
nation or Government
to exalt themselves by the
debasement of the less
favoured portions of humanity
tThere is even a general willingness
to make considerable sacrifices
for, and to acknowledge the duty
10 194
of their civilization - But every
now and then we are forced
to hear of the happy homesteads
of English settlers made desolate
by hordes of ruthless savages -
tThousands of sheep ^ & cattle are driven
off to be devoured in the mountain
fastnesses - The gardens and
fields of the comfortable family
families are left desolate while those
whose industry would in
the course of a few years
have rendered them independent,
if they have escaped with
life, are reduced to beggary -
English troops are then
sent to chastise the Kaffreirs
and avenge for these fearful outrages,
for it is quite abhorrent
to the English nature^ure to leave
England's her children unprotected
in the presence of these such
barbarians - The English
soldier fights as bravely there
as anywhere else - The fatigues
of bush fighting are excessively
severe - and their privation
which must be ^ endured in following a
brave and crafty foe ^ are such
as can scarcely be imagined
by those who never saw
the fighting grounds - The
Officers are decimated
by perpetual anxiety -
Kaffreir bullets, and the
11 195
dead certainty that their labours
will be appreciated nowhere,
Millions of Pounds are
cheerfully paid by ^ out of the British
Treasury for the defence
of the Colonial Frontier,
but notwithstanding the
most lavish expenditure
of money and men there
never is not the smallest probability
that ^ ^ a future the nextanother outbreak will
be prevented -

As the period of our visit
to the Cape happened to be coincident
with the termination of ga grand
experiment at a ^ towards a practical
solution of the great CaffreKaffir
difficulty noticed above - though ^ and the
subject being
rather out of
my line and
certainly not
one on which
I love to dwell
I shall only
offer a rapid
sketch
# The interval between CaffreKaffir
outbreaks had been prolonged
for a great many years
by what has been called
the Glenelg or "philanthropic
policy" - This though not perfectly well
worked out faultless was worthy of the
man whose name it bears,
and incomparably the least
expensive to the mother country
This policy was put an
12 196
an end to and a severer system
strongly advocated on the Frontier
called the "DurbanD'Urban policy" was
tried - The former treated the
C CaffresKaffirs as rational creatures
and presupposed that they had
some sort of natural title to
their lands and if we could
keep a treaty so could they -
It also went on the basis
of the observation of common
honesty among ourselves as
well as among the KaffirsCaffres
and It was remarkably cheap
to the mother country -

The DurbanD'Urban policy presupposed
a willingness on the part of
the Dutch Colonists to turn out
and exterminate the KaffirsCaffers
if only allowed to do it in
their own way - This could
not be put into operation
because it is a libel to say
that the Dutch in the Colony
are what the bloodthirsty people
this policy represented them
to be -

Another plan was tried
by a gentleman conversant
with Indian Affairs - He wished
to adopt the Indian plan of
arming one part of the KCaffirs
against another and disciplined
a large body of the KCaffir police -
13 197
then elected himself the paramount
chief of KaffirCaffreland - He was
unconsciously dealing with the
most devotedly loyal people
on earth - They never desert
leave ^ the ranks of their chiefs as
French, Russians & even
Englishmen do desert to the enemy
So when the watchword was
given by the great organ of
the war party "Send away
SandillahSandile" - The KaffirCaffre
"Sippa-hisSipahi" went off en masse
to join their proper standard
in the AnnatolansAnatolians - Men whose
loyalty to their chiefs has
been but ^ only barely equalled but not
surpassed by that of the
Highlanders to the Pretender
might one would think
have been turned to better
account than have every
feeling of their devotedness
outraged by a foreigner
pretending to place himself
in the position of their
paramount chief SandillahSandile
To any one acquainted
with the political constitution
of the South African tribes
no step could have been
devised better adapted for
rousing the wrath of the
entire KaffirCaffre people than
14 198
most impotent stab at their
nationality - Not even SandillahSandile
himself could have invented
a more certain and efficient
means of rallying all the
chivalry of kCaffirland around
him than that "a white man
who had been made a chief
by a woman should depose
him who had been made a
chief by God" -

After a desperately
prolonged struggle in which
upwards of two millions of
money were spent. the
DurbanD'Urban policy worked to
beThe rather dear bought conclusion
was reached that the D'Urban
policy is not the solution of the
KaffirCaffre difficulty for it
was officially declared
by competent authority that
a KaffirCaffre war was equal to one
with the Circassians or
Algerine Arabs and SandillahSandile
was not sent away -

An experiment had
thus been fairly tried at the
time of our arrival at the
Cape aton a large scale
and in exact accordance
with the ideasviews of a large
party on the Frontier - The
measures were as severe
15 199
as the most bloody minded
could desire, yet we cannot
exterminate a single African
tribe - The race is imperishable
as other things hereafter to be
noticed indicate this as well
Whether the Kaffirs are the
descendants of Ishmael may
be gravely questioned - but
certain it is they do in
spite of all we can do "dwell
bravely in the presence of all
their brethren" - Their past
seems to forbode that if we
follow the fighting policy
we can only hope for a
permanent peace when
we have depopulated all the
country between Graham's
townGrahamstown and TimbuctuTimbuktu - And
as we have taken so long and
been at so much expense
with such small progress
in that direction, such a
consummation implies
a postponement of the
Millennnium to please the
war party for some fifteen
thousand years to come

If we knew the
causes of the KaffirCaffre wars
a remedy might be found
but since the annulment
cancelmentcancellation of the rational
16 200
Glenelg policy all those who
pretend to knowledge of
the difficulty have made
such ridiculous mistakes
in practice and are at
so much variance in their
opinions the enquirer is
quite at sea - Some aver
that KCaffir wars have
been rendered necessary
by the restless thievish
propensities of our savage
neighbours and not
from any injustice or
aggression either on the
part of the government
or of the inhabitants of
the Frontier - or was
(Or must be around in because
it is a fact true of this
as of other colonies that the
native population becomes
worse and not better by
from its contact with civilization
and a professedly Christian
people adding that the
grasping encroachments
of the white man from
year to year on the native
lands is neither an unlikely
mode of teaching the KCaffirs
that honesty is one of
the virtues

Or And to complete
17 201
the catalogue of alleged causes
the KaffirsCaffres themselves say
"No white man is without
a book - Is it God who gave
this book bids him think
of blood - Some white men
come and say "the KaffirsCaffres
steal" - but the white men
are the robbers - God made
a boundary by the sea
and white man cross it
to rob us of our country
When the son of God came
down from Heaven you
white men killed him - ^ It was not black
men ^ who did not do that -
Englishmen make laws about
promises about the land
and break them - They make
a boundary and then take
it away - The reason why
we fight is we do not wish
to live under the English - Is it
God who sent the Englishman
accross the sea to take our
country - Is it God who created
him bids him come and
rule over the chiefs of
other countries - Is that
right - We are tired of the
Englishman on account
of his bad conduct - If he
kills me both he and I will
have to answer before God" *
* Extracts of a speech of SandillahSandile
to R R Renton United Presbyterian church Scotland

18 202
Now these assertions possess
so much of the recriminatory
character one cannot feel
confidence in either - Still
less can we concieveconceive of those
who have been benefitted by
KaffirCaffre wars giving an
opinion worth a straw
Yet it is a remarkable
feature in thes case that those
who from a residence on
the spot where supplies
* from England are chiefly
spent and where men
with their wits about them
may make fortunes in
the philanthropic business
of aiding the troops are
generally quite decided
in their opinions as
to the necessity of severe
measures with the KaffirsCaffres
They are particularly active
in pointing out the causes
of the KCaffir wars and boldly
criticise the tactics of generals
the conduct of the governors -
the thieving of the KCaffirs &
the behaviour of missionaries
Their lugubrious wailings of
these over the afflicted
Frontier farmers are
peculiarly affecting, and as
the body of Frontier farmers of war
supplies have become
19 203
a moneyed community
possessing great influence
their volunteer lamentations
over the frontier farmers of
cattle may well lead some
to suspect that the cry of
distress made in their behalf
is somewhat ^ like the cry of
agricultural distress which
formerly was rife in
England That was as
non-indicative
of suffering
among the
real farmers
as this is
non-indicative
of distress
in the real
sufferers
by Caffre wars
Real distress
existed in
both cases
but Caffre
war provides
no relief
to the needy
in either
case - While
they do
give competencies
to the men
who "give
tongue" - And had a "Times
commissioner" accompanied
the army ion the Cape Frontier
the English public might
have known ere this
the difference between the
real and the feigned Frontier
farmers

It would be a great
mistake to imagine that the Cape people
as a body are benefitted by
a state of warfare - It is
a blight on the prosperity of
the country - But since
there is a ^ small party which has
grown great by KCaffirre
wars, and they are especially
divided in their opinions
as to the causes of the outbreaks
but and always stoutly hold to
the opiniondoctrine that England
must pay the expenses
It might be well to
ask the KCaffirsres - We have
20 204
always but one side of
the question in KCaffirre
difficulties - We never
hear of our defeats except
byfrom the defeated forces
In aeach war The aggregate is defeat
while all the defea details
are victoryies Such a
discrepancy could not
occur if we had the
KaffirCaffre opinions too and -
perhaps collision might
be avoided ^ altogether if they
were allowed a voice
in the solution of the difficulty
An English military official
is well known to have
broken his word of honour
and thereby got a Caffre chief
into his hands - We never
got another - And though
one governor declared in
a public dispatch that
"he had slain 980 000 Caffres
and and 6,000 Caffre
chiefs and returned triumphant
and victorious" wehe never
had a single live Caffre
chief to shewshow - SandillahSandile
declared that "though killed
his bones would rise
up and fight - aye and
his bones' bones would
fight against the English forever"

21 205
This proclamationdispatch was read
written while we were at the Cape
The war went on for about
half a year afterwards but as
the entire Caffre population
has been stated to be only 94,000
I have never ceased to regret
that we had not a Times
commissioner on the spot
as well as at the Crimea - It would
be so interesting to discover how
the Caffre bones got up and fought
like Benjamin Franklin's
dead flies from Madeira wine
and fought with Sir George
Cathcart for months after-
-wards - If England must
pay such enormous sums
and her Government isas isit
certainly the casedoes wishes to deal
fairly and fight fairly too in
cases of necessity, by all
means let us hear both
sides of the question - What
do the Caffres and our soldiers
say? To whom do our soldiers
refer as those who alone are
benefitted by the wars? Let us
hear both sides and not go
blundering on at the bidding of
those who not worthse than the
generality of men are in a position
to make even the blood of the
English soldier profitable - Let us
have a "Times commissioner"

Without supposing these
people to be either worse than
the general mass of humanity
or that they have acted
otherwise than most men
would have done when
placed in circumstances
where fortunes were to be
made out of the supplies
sent out from England
it must be conceded that
the mother country has
gone as far in gratifying
their whim for Kaffir
wars as the most leech-
-like portion of humanity
could desire - Their favourite
"D'Urban policy" can not be
worked because as Sir
Harry Smith fully proved
by his proclamation inviting
(insulting?) the Colonial
farmers to "exterminate"
the Kaffirs" the Dutch areunder
English law ^ are not the bloodthirsty savages
which the misanthropic
policy presupposes - And
even at among the Kaffreir
war party itself there is
no hope of working it
207
And if ^ also in addition he finds the statement I have
made of the invariable friendliness
& honesty of the Bechuanas such as I describe
that he and find it advisable
to make ^ the same a relaxation of the
powder ordinance in favour
of our friends as we have
done in favour of our
enemies (the Boers) the
influence and honour of the
British name will be both
enhanced

208
children now openly practised
in the Northern part of the Trans-
vaal territory was carefully
concealed but immediately
on their IndependanceIndependence being
acknowledged They madmade the
foray against Sechele to regain
the slaves the emancipation
of which having been the
grievance for which most
of them left the Colony -
And they proclaimed that
the English had now
handed over the whole region
to their will This the
natives who had the highest
respect for the English name
did not believe but as
the assertion of the Boers
seems to be backed by
the operation of the Powder
ordinance weour fame is
in danger of being tarnished

Now I do not wish
to express an opinion on
the policy of the IndependanceIndependence
of the Transvaal Boers,
but the that I do beg
that that the Government
powder OrdOrdinance - so proper for the
Kaffirs on the East should
not be so worked as to
give the impression of
connivance in the enslavement
of the friendly tribes in the West
This impression spreading
rapidly in the far Interior
will in all probability as
made powerfully destruct my
own future efforts as the
good opinion which had
circulated far and wide
over vast regions formerly
aided my progress And it
will tend to the still farther
development of English
commerce and civilisation

If it should be your
pleasure to attend to this very
important subject I would
humbyhumbly beg you to bring
the subject before the
Present Colonial Governor
Sir George Grey and if
His Excellency will examine
the different eulogiums which
have been passed by different
Colonial Governments or
the Griqua chief Waterboer
for his faithful adherence
ofto a treaty for the defence
of the North West Frontier
during twenty years
209
being numbered among the patients -
Our Maker has surrounded us with
beauty in his fair creation, and
believing that we ought to cultivate
the taste for the beautiful and good
my mind I have been in the habit of
admiring his handy works
wherever manifested in nature
or man - This habit of mind
will probably appear in these
pages for I now look with
kindlier feeling on every landscape
and on every class of my
fellow men than persons of a
bilious temperament may
think advisable -

and now to The objects which I had in view
may be understood by what follows
Having left England in 1846 with
instructions from the London Missionary
Society to endeavour to carry Christianity
into the countries North or Kuruman
or Lattakoo then their farthest station
inland from the Cape I possessed
an intense desire
to become a
pioneer of civilisation
shewingshowing that
my medical
education rendered
me suitable for
running up the
flag for other
missionaries -
and I aAt once I
proceeded in the direction indicated -
and iIn order to attain an accurate
knowledge of the language I separated
myself for several months from
European society and gained thereby
a knowledge of the people and
their w language and way of
thinking which haves proved
of immense value in intercourse
with them ever since - The tribe
to &
Before I giveBefore I renew & narrate our colloquy let me
offer a very brief sketch of this remarkable man who has
embraced Christianity but expounds its doctrines
to his people et c et c
210
for when the rest of the Colony
sent levies of volunteers
and even the Hottentots
turned out by hundreds
The Shopocracy of Graham's
TownGrahamstown to whom every returned
officer points out as
those who alone are benefittdbenefitted
by protective wars, musterdmustered
only 36 thirty six most
of whom where ^ Hottentot substitutes
who and remained only a
fortnight under arms.
No wonder that Sir George
Cathcart complained bitterly of
that not a man of those
for whom he was fighting
would aid him and as the
war drew to a close, uttered
uttered an ominous threat
against those who continued
to keep up the irritation
of the war for their own ends

The influence of the
party referred to may be
understood when it is
mentioned that Sir Harry
Smith adopted the watch
word which the organ of
the party perennially proclaimed
as that of the war
211
declared would shewshow the causes
of the CKaffir war and Hotenttot
rebellion to be "the missionaries"

Now the proportion which
the community which has been
enriched by Kaffir wars bears
to the missionaries may be
about five hundred to five
And though the latter have on
every occasion lost everything
article of property of worldly goods they possessed if
they are really the the mono-
-maniacs who delight in
arson and murder they have
been asserted believed to be - it is no more
than patriotism in these
five hundred who have always
been sane enough to extract
the sweet out of the bitter - line
-- their "draw honest gain from the
necessary evils of war" - to
denounce the mad originators
of this most calamitous
state - This they vigourouslyvigorously did -
by the public
press ^ and in doing so the entire
body felt that their organ acted
nobly -

A Hottentot officer named
Botha was fixed upon as apparently
deeply implicated in the ^ late rebellion &
war - and as he was known
